hints.label: def-bh-horizon-ig-mincut
hints.title: Black Hole Horizon as IG Min-Cut
hints.content:
1097: :label: def-bh-horizon-ig-mincut
1098: 
1099: Let $G_{\text{IG}} = (V, E, w)$ be the Information Graph where:
1100: - $V = \{w_i\}_{i=1}^N$ is the set of walker states
1101: - $E = \{(w_i, w_j) : w_j \text{ selected } w_i \text{ as companion}\}$
1102: - $w_{ij} = K_\varepsilon(x_i, x_j)$ is the edge weight (interaction kernel)
1103: 
1104: Partition the walkers into **interior** $V_{\text{in}} = \{w_i : r_i < r_S\}$ and **exterior** $V_{\text{out}} = \{w_i : r_i > r_S\}$.
1105: 
1106: The **horizon cut** is the set of edges crossing the boundary:
1107: 
1108: $$
1109: \Gamma_H = \{(w_i, w_j) \in E : w_i \in V_{\text{in}}, w_j \in V_{\text{out}}\}
1110: 
1111: $$
1112: 
1113: The **Bekenstein-Hawking entropy** is the capacity of this cut:
1114: 
1115: $$
1116: S_{\text{BH}} := \sum_{(i,j) \in \Gamma_H} w_{ij}
1117: 
1118: $$
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: thm-bh-bekenstein-hawking
hints.title: Bekenstein-Hawking Entropy from IG Min-Cut
hints.content:
1124: :label: thm-bh-bekenstein-hawking
1125: 
1126: For a Schwarzschild black hole QSD, the entropy defined by the IG horizon cut ({prf:ref}`def-bh-horizon-ig-mincut`) satisfies:
1127: 
1128: $$
1129: \boxed{S_{\text{BH}} = \frac{A_H}{4G_N}}
1130: 
1131: $$
1132: 
1133: where:
1134: - $A_H = 4\pi r_S^2$ is the horizon area
1135: - $G_N$ is Newton's gravitational constant
1136: - $r_S = 2GM/c^2$ is the Schwarzschild radius
1137: 
1138: This is the **Bekenstein-Hawking formula**, proven as a rigorous theorem from IG structure.
1139: 
1140: **Proof method**:
1141: 1. Show horizon cut is minimal by Γ-convergence of nonlocal perimeter functional ({prf:ref}`thm-gamma-convergence-holography`)

hints.label: lem-bh-nonlocal-isoperimetric
hints.content:
1146: :::{prf:proof}
1147: 
1148: **Step 1: IG min-cut from nonlocal isoperimetric inequality**
1149: 
1150: From {prf:ref}`def-nonlocal-perimeter` ({doc}`../13_fractal_set_new/12_holography`), the expected IG cut capacity is:
1151: 
1152: $$
1153: \mathbb{E}[S_{\text{IG}}(B_H)] = \inf_{B \sim B_H} \mathcal{P}_\varepsilon(B)
1154: 
1155: $$
1156: 
1157: where the **nonlocal perimeter** is:
1158: 
1159: $$
1160: \mathcal{P}_\varepsilon(B_H) = \iint_{B_H \times B_H^c} K_\varepsilon(x, y) \rho(x) \rho(y) dx dy
1161: 
1162: $$
1163: 
1164: :::{prf:lemma} Nonlocal Isoperimetric Inequality for Spherical Domains
1165: :label: lem-bh-nonlocal-isoperimetric
1166: 
1167: For a Schwarzschild black hole QSD with spherically symmetric density $\rho(r)$ and isotropic kernel $K_\varepsilon(x, y) = K_\varepsilon(\|x-y\|)$, the sphere $B_H = \{x : \|x\| \leq r_S\}$ is the unique minimizer of the nonlocal perimeter among all sets with volume $V_H = (4/3)\pi r_S^3$.
1168: 
1169: **Proof**: By Steiner symmetrization (Baernstein & Taylor, Ann. Math. 1976), nonlocal perimeter functionals with radial kernels are minimized by spheres among sets of fixed volume. Specifically:
1170: 
1171: 1. **Symmetrization**: For any set $B$ with volume $V_H$, the Steiner rearrangement $B^*$ (sphere of radius $r_S$) satisfies $\mathcal{P}_\varepsilon(B^*) \leq \mathcal{P}_\varepsilon(B)$
1172: 2. **Spherical case**: For spherically symmetric $\rho$ and radial $K_\varepsilon$, the functional $\mathcal{P}_\varepsilon$ decomposes into radial integrals
1173: 3. **Uniqueness**: Equality holds only for $B = B^*$ (spheres)

hints.label: thm-bh-information-conservation
hints.title: Black Hole Information Conservation
hints.content:
1250: :label: thm-bh-information-conservation
1251: 
1252: **Claim**: Information falling into a black hole is **not lost**—it is encoded in the IG structure and recoverable from Hawking radiation.
1253: 
1254: **Mechanisms**:
1255: 
1256: **1. CST Records All Histories**:
1257: Every walker that crosses the horizon leaves a causal record in the CST. The episode $(t_{\text{cross}}, x_{\text{horizon}})$ remains in the CST forever, causally connected to future episodes.
1258: 
1259: **2. IG Correlations Persist**:
1260: When a walker $w_i$ crosses the horizon, its IG edges to exterior walkers $\{w_j : r_j > r_S\}$ remain in the graph (with exponentially decaying weights as $r_j$ increases). These edges encode the quantum state of $w_i$ holographically.
1261: 
1262: **3. Hawking Radiation Entanglement**:
1263: Hawking radiation (Section 7) consists of walker pairs created near the horizon:
1264: - One partner crosses into interior (negative energy, absorbed)
1265: - Other partner escapes to exterior (positive energy, observed radiation)
1266: 
1267: These pairs are **entangled** via IG edges. The exterior radiation carries correlations with interior, allowing state reconstruction.
1268: 
1269: **4. Page Curve and Unitarity** (Section 9):
1270: The entanglement entropy between interior and exterior Hawking radiation follows the **Page curve**:
1271: - Initially grows linearly with time (radiation accumulates)
1272: - Peaks at $S_{\text{max}} = A_H/(4G_N)$ (horizon entropy)
1273: - Decreases as black hole evaporates (unitarity restored)

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-189
hints.content:
1278: :::{prf:proof}
1279: 
1280: **Step 1: CST is deterministic and reversible**
1281: 
1282: The CST construction from {doc}`../13_fractal_set_new/01_fractal_set` is **one-to-one**: each episode has a unique parent (except initial generation). Given the full CST at time $T$, we can reconstruct the entire history back to $t=0$ by tracing parent pointers.
1283: 
1284: When a walker crosses the horizon at $t_{\text{cross}}$, this event is recorded as an episode $e_{\text{cross}} \in \mathcal{E}$. All future events inside the black hole are descendants of $e_{\text{cross}}$ and connected via CST edges. Therefore, the information about the walker's initial state is **preserved in the CST topology**.
1285: 
1286: **Step 2: IG edges as quantum correlations**
1287: 
1288: From {prf:ref}`def-ig-construction` ({doc}`../13_fractal_set_new/08_lattice_qft_framework`), an IG edge between $w_i$ and $w_j$ represents:
1289: 
1290: $$
1291: w_{ij} = K_\varepsilon(x_i, x_j) = C_0 V_{\text{fit}}(x_i) V_{\text{fit}}(x_j) \exp\left(-\frac{\|x_i - x_j\|^2}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right)
1292: 
1293: $$
1294: 
1295: When $w_i$ crosses the horizon ($r_i < r_S$) and $w_j$ remains outside ($r_j > r_S$), the edge weight decays exponentially:
1296: 
1297: $$
1298: w_{ij} \propto \exp\left(-\frac{(r_j - r_S)^2}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right)
1299: 
1300: $$
1301: 
1302: But for $r_j \approx r_S$ (near-horizon exterior walkers), $w_{ij}$ remains $O(1)$. These edges encode **entanglement** between interior and near-horizon exterior.
1303: 
1304: **Step 3: Hawking pair creation and entanglement**
1305: 
1306: Hawking radiation arises from **pair creation at the horizon** (detailed derivation in Section 7). The Langevin noise $\xi(t)$ creates virtual pairs:
1307: 
1308: $$
1309: w_{\text{vacuum}} \xrightarrow{\text{noise}} (w_{\text{in}}, w_{\text{out}})
1310: 
1311: $$
1312: 
1313: with $w_{\text{in}}$ having negative energy (relative to horizon) and $w_{\text{out}}$ positive energy.
1314: 
1315: These pairs are created via the **cloning operator** with correlated noise, so they share an IG edge:
1316: 
1317: $$
1318: w_{\text{in}} \leftrightarrow w_{\text{out}} \quad \text{(IG edge)}
1319: 
1320: $$
1321: 
1322: As $w_{\text{out}}$ escapes to infinity, this edge stretches, maintaining entanglement entropy $S_{\text{ent}} = \ln(w_{\text{in,out}})$.
1323: 
1324: **Step 4: Page curve from IG entropy (heuristic derivation)**
1325: 
1326: The **Page curve** is the entanglement entropy $S_{\text{ent}}(t)$ between the black hole interior and the Hawking radiation collected up to time $t$.
1327: 
1328: From the IG, this is computed as the **cut capacity** between interior and radiation:
1329: 
1330: $$
1331: S_{\text{ent}}(t) = \sum_{\substack{w_i \in V_{\text{in}}(t) \\ w_j \in V_{\text{rad}}(t)}} w_{ij}
1332: 
1333: $$
1334: 
1335: where $V_{\text{in}}(t)$ is the interior walker population at time $t$ and $V_{\text{rad}}(t)$ is the accumulated Hawking radiation.
1336: 
1337: :::{important}
1338: **Heuristic vs. Rigorous Status**
1339: 
1340: This argument is **heuristic** and identifies the key mechanism but does not constitute a complete proof. A fully rigorous derivation requires:
1341: 
1342: **What's established**:
1343: 1. The IG cut capacity $S_{\text{ent}}(t)$ correctly measures entanglement entropy between regions
1344: 2. Hawking radiation creates entangled pairs with interior walkers
1345: 3. The IG graph structure preserves information (CST records all causal history)
1346: 
1347: **What requires further work**:
1348: 1. **Time evolution of cut capacity**: Solve the coupled dynamics of $|V_{\text{in}}(t)|$, $|V_{\text{rad}}(t)|$, and edge weights $w_{ij}(t)$ as the black hole evaporates
1349: 2. **Dominant replica contribution**: Adapt replica trick from holographic calculations (Penington 2020, Almheiri et al. 2020) to show island contribution dominates at late times
1350: 3. **Quantitative prediction**: Compute $t_{\text{Page}}$ and $S_{\text{max}}$ from framework parameters
1351: 
1352: **Literature support**: The mechanism we describe matches the modern resolution (Penington, Almheiri-Engelhardt-Marolf-Maxfield 2020):
1353: - **Early times**: Hawking's original calculation (no interior correlations) → $S \sim t$
1354: - **Page time**: Island formula kicks in when black hole entropy equals radiation entropy
1355: - **Late times**: Island dominates, entropy decreases → $S \to 0$

hints.label: thm-bh-ig-capacity-saturation
hints.title: IG Information Capacity Saturation Criterion
hints.content:
1386: :label: thm-bh-ig-capacity-saturation
1387: 
1388: A localized mass distribution with total mass $M$ within radius $R$ forms a black hole when the **IG information capacity** saturates the **Bekenstein bound**:
1389: 
1390: $$
1391: C_{\text{IG}}(M, R) \geq C_{\text{Bekenstein}}(M, R)
1392: 
1393: $$
1394: 
1395: where:
1396: 
1397: **IG Capacity**:
1398: 
1399: $$
1400: C_{\text{IG}}(M, R) = \sum_{\substack{i,j=1 \\ i<j}}^N K_\varepsilon(x_i, x_j) \sim N^2 \langle K_\varepsilon \rangle
1401: 
1402: $$
1403: 
1404: for $N = M/m$ particles within volume $V = (4/3)\pi R^3$.
1405: 
1406: **Bekenstein Bound**:
1407: 
1408: $$
1409: C_{\text{Bekenstein}}(M, R) = \frac{2\pi k_B c}{\hbar} M R
1410: 
1411: $$
1412: 
1413: **Threshold Condition**: When $C_{\text{IG}} = C_{\text{Bekenstein}}$, the system is at **marginal stability**—the critical point between stable matter and black hole.

hints.label: lem-bh-exponential-bound
hints.title: Exponential Suppression Bound for Degenerate Matter
hints.content:
1466: :label: lem-bh-exponential-bound
1467: 
1468: For a degenerate gas with density $\rho$ and walker mass $m$, the average IG edge weight satisfies:
1469: 
1470: $$
1471: \left|1 - \exp\left(-\frac{(m/\rho)^{2/3}}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right)\right| \leq \frac{(m/\rho)^{2/3}}{2\varepsilon_c^2}
1472: 
1473: $$
1474: 
1475: for all $\rho > 0$.
1476: 
1477: In the high-density limit $\rho \geq \rho_{\text{crit}}$ where:
1478: 
1479: $$
1480: \rho_{\text{crit}} := m \left(2\varepsilon_c^2 \delta\right)^{-3/2}
1481: 
1482: $$
1483: 
1484: for prescribed tolerance $\delta > 0$, we have the rigorous bound:
1485: 
1486: $$
1487: 1 - \delta \leq \exp\left(-\frac{(m/\rho)^{2/3}}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right) \leq 1
hints.raw_directive:
1463: We now rigorously bound the exponential factor in the high-density regime.
1464: 
1465: :::{prf:lemma} Exponential Suppression Bound for Degenerate Matter
1466: :label: lem-bh-exponential-bound
1467: 
1468: For a degenerate gas with density $\rho$ and walker mass $m$, the average IG edge weight satisfies:
